text: (bright upbeat music)
Before I get started,
I would like to say thanks
to "Chemical & Engineering News"
for this wonderful opportunity.
And of course extend a warm congratulations
to all of the other awardees.
So before I get started,
I'd like to tell you a bit about myself.
I grew up in the foothills
of the Blue Ridge Mountains in South Carolina,
and I grew up playing a lot of outdoor sports.
And so actually this is how I paid for college.
I went to Lander University,
a small liberal arts college on a softball scholarship.
And you can see here this picture of the lovely team
that I had the opportunity to play with.
Lander, like I said, was quite small.
I didn't have the opportunity to do a lot of research,
but I had one small research project during my studies.
I was studying chemistry and mathematics.
And this research project
was with an organic chemistry professor, Dr. Pete Vahjen.
And he is actually the person
who inspired me to go to graduate school.
So one day I was in the lab working,
and he came in and he sat down and he said,
"Wendy, where are you going to school?
Where are you going to graduate school?"
And I said, "I think I'm not cut out for graduate school."
He jumps up and he says,
"If I made it through graduate school,
you're gonna be amazing."
So he ran into his office and he came back
and he held a document.
And he said, "By next week,
you should have filled this out."
And actually, that was my first graduate school application.
And so I ended up studying for my PhD
under the guidance of Professor Shiou-Jyh,
was working on low-dimensional magnetism,
and learning to characterize,
basically, inorganic materials.
A wonderful time at Clemson.
Dr. Hwu taught me basically how to do science
and write papers and proposals,
which you can imagine is really important
at this stage of my career.
After Clemson,
I decided that I wanted to get a bit more well-rounded
and do some advanced characterization.
And I applied for a position with Dr. Craig Brown
at the NIST Center For Neutron Research.
And he really gave me an opportunity
to do neutron scattering,
despite the fact that I had no previous experience.
During this time, I also wrote a proposal
and it ended up that I received a fellowship
that paid for my studies during the time with Craig.
One day during my second year of my postdoc,
Craig came in and he said,
"The new Center For Neutron Research is gonna be shutting
down due to an expansion project."
And basically, "What would you like to do?"
And of course, without thinking, I said,
"I'd like to go to Berkeley and study under the guidance
of Jeff Arnold."
So during my studies at NIST,
I was looking at small molecule interactions
in porus media.
Jeff is an expert in metal organic frameworks,
so this seemed like a good next step.
Craig phone up Jeff,
they talk, they set up a way for me
to basically go and live in Berkeley and study.
After that, I returned back to this to finish my postdoc
Jeff phoned me one day and said,
"Wendy, I know you fell in love with California
and you really wanna come back.
There's a job at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab
that you should consider applying for."
So I looked into it, I ended up applying for this position.
And three months later,
I was lucky enough to be moving back to California.
I was working at the molecular Foundry,
basically starting a new user program,
focused on the synthesis and characterization of forest
materials under the guidance of Omar Yaghi
who is one of the individuals credited
with actually founding the MOF field.
During this time,
I basically had an opportunity
to set up my own research program.
And so I decided that I would go after faculty positions.
And after looking around a bit,
I applied for a position at EPFL in Switzerland.
And of course, since I've been here,
I've stuck with my American roots.
I'm still playing baseball, you can see,
but I'm also learning French and learning to ski,
and if you can see the hole in my pants
you'll know that I'm not staying on my feet very much.
So more importantly,
I'm surrounded by this beautiful country
that inspires the chemistry that we're doing every day.
So we're working on environmental-based work in our lab,
and this is part of our team.
So a wonderful group of people,
I have the opportunity now to give back
what these individuals you see before you
have so graciously given to me.
So I have the opportunity to mentor a group of scientists
now at EPFL.
And so with that, what we're doing,
we're basically working on constructing porous materials,
known as metal, organic frameworks.
These are the most porous materials in the world,
and they have a lot of benefits that they can positively
impact our planet.
Throughout my talk you'll see
that I have these sustainable development goals, or symbols,
and you can look for those.
MOFs can make a really strong
impact in achieving these 2030 goals.
So what is the metal organic framework?
It's classically defined as a material
that's constructed by metal ions or
metal ion clusters shown here in blue.
And these are interlinked by organic-based ligands.
And these predefined, organic ligands are fantastic, right?
They give us a lot of chemical tolerability.
So you can imagine that we can turn
their shape and their size
to turn the pore shape and the pore size of the material.
Furthermore, we can functionalize the surface
of those materials and kind of control
how these materials interact
with their surrounding environments.
And of course, guess species that are gonna go inside.
So if you take a closer look at this material,
you'll note that it has very high densities of very small
pores, so it's mostly open space.
And as a result of these, this high density
of nano size channels,
they actually have record breaking surface areas.
So the record at the moment is about 7,800 meters squared
in a single gram.
And just to give you an idea of how much surface area this
it's equivalent to that of a European football field.
So not only can we chemically tune them
to selectively grab certain guests,
we also have very large surface areas
and this means that we can put a lot of things inside.
As a result, my group is working on separations.
The reason that this is so important is because currently
about 15% of global energy is expended industrially,
on gas and liquid-based separations.
And I should tell you this number's already huge
without the implementation of large scale carbon capture.
We would expect that that number would go up significantly
should we implement this on large scales.
So really our group goals, I would tell you are twofold.
It is to reduce the energy input
into existing gas and liquid-based separations.
And the second is to basically try to make separations
that are deemed impossible now possible
through the design of new forest materials.
So for me, I believe the most important separation
of our time is of course related
to the capture of greenhouse gases,
like carbon dioxide.
As you probably all know,
this is implicated, of course, in global warming.
The key is is that if we wanna capture CO2,
we have to know where it comes from.
And the two largest point sources are gonna be automobile
exhaust, as well as large scale power plants
used to produce electricity.
So here you can see one of those flues
coming out of a power plant
and basically carbon dioxide coming out of the flue
is mixed with lots of different small molecules
like nitrogen, water, and oxygen.
And the key is is that these small molecules
have very similar sizes and shapes,
and so if we wanna capture CO2,
we really have to design a material
that has molecule-specific interactions
on its internal surface.
So then what we can do is simply stream these materials
through, or stream the gases through our materials.
We can capture that CO2, as you can see here,
and then we can emit the less harmful gases, for instance,
into the atmosphere.
Once our materials are saturated,
you can, for instance, heat those up and release that CO2,
if you wanted to store it for instance,
long-term, underground,
or if we've been super-clever,
we've maybe engineered reactive sites on the inside
of that material so that we can then activate that CO2
and potentially convert it back
into value added chemicals and fuels.
In addition to CO2 capture,
another extremely important separation of course,
is water purification.
As humans it's required, of course, to sustain life.
Unfortunately about 11% of our population
has no access to clean water.
We expect with continued climate change
this number is gonna rise dramatically.
So what we're doing is basically trying to design
course materials so that we can extract
some of the most harmful contaminants in water.
And so here, I'm showing you a MOF.
We've done something a little bit unique.
We've learned how to append short chain polymers
inside our MOFs,
and what you'll note is on this polymer backbone
it's really got some nice functionality
that can complex, for instance, heavy metals in water.
The key is is that these short chain polymers
basically enhance the MOF performance quite significantly.
And so that's what I'm showing you here.
You'll see lead on the left and mercury on the right.
So in the gray,
you'll see the initial concentration of lead and mercury.
We've treated it with our metal organic framework.
In red you'll see the concentrations decrease a little.
However, when we treat it with our composite,
our MOF polymer composite,
we see that the extraction efficiency
is improved by factors of 60 and 90 times.
So we get below drinkable levels
and within a matter of seconds.
And we can take out large quantities of these metals.
Interestingly enough,
the materials are also extremely selective.
So what this means is that if we put our materials
in a very complex matrix,
it doesn't decrease its efficiency.
So here I'm showing you an extremely complex matrix,
that's sea water.
What you'll note is that the concentration of sodium
is 14,000 times that of the lead that we've swapped in.
what we found is that the material will selectively remove
the lead and leave behind these other metal
in the solution, which is great.
Because of the material's performance,
we've begun incorporating them into filter devices.
So we formed these little MOF beads.
We flow contaminated water through those.
So here you can see the starting concentration
of lead, 600 parts per billion.
We note that when we flow it through
we're well below the EPA limit, it's about 15 PPB,
which is what is deemed drinkable by the EPA.
And what we find in this flow-through experiment
is that we can actually purify
with a single gram of material about 10.8 liters of water.
And this is great because it's already competitive
with commercial absorbents.
Furthermore, we know that we can improve this quite a lot
with improved polymerization,
as well as better structuring processes to form our beads.
The selectivity that you saw in the previous slide
really excited me quite a lot.
So I began to think of other ways
that we can apply these materials.
And the first thing that came to mind
were high value metals.
So high value commodities.
And the reason is because the mining industry
contains loads of energy.
And so the key is,
is that we then incorporate these metals
into a variety of products, like everybody uses cell phones,
but the problem is, is that at the end of their life,
we're basically throwing these cell phones into landfills.
And so, because we would like to make this process circular
rather than linear, like it is at the moment,
we're basically trying to design course materials
so that we can now extract those precious metals
from a variety of different types of waste streams.
So here I'm showing you the same exact MOF,
but we've basically changed our polymer inside.
Now we're able to selectively extract gold
from a variety of different waste streams
that includes industrial wastewater, sewage sludge,
electronic waste, river water,
and we've already also begun to see some gold concentration
from the sea, which is very exciting.
So I can't show you all of these different matrices
but I'd like to show you at least one.
We're all familiar with what this is.
This is a CPU that we've taken from an old computer.
If you look, you'll see that it mostly consists of copper,
nickel, and gold.
We've basically just grinded these metals off,
then we dissolve them in a solution
and we throw our sponge inside.
Okay, so what I'm showing you here
is that we can selectively extract the gold
and leave behind the copper and nickel.
And I note that the copper has a concentration
that's 200 times that of the gold.
And despite this, our material
still selectively extracts the gold.
We can basically then concentrate that gold inside
and what we essentially do once it's full,
it's reached its capacity,
which is about one gram of gold per gram of composite,
we then destroy that sponge,
and what we're left with is 23.9 carat gold on the backend.
This is the highest purity reported to date
for such an extraction process.
And this is directly related
to the material's high selectivity, as I mentioned before.
So if you look at the, the extraction, it's about six,
a little over 600 times more selective, for instance,
for copper than it is, or for gold than it is for copper.
So with that, we are continuing to design materials,
hopefully highly selective materials
for a lot of different types of separations.
We would essentially like to be able to get the holy grail,
and that is begin to mine things, for instance,
from the ocean.
For the materials that we have that are performing well,
we're starting to scale those materials up.
We're doing so using grain chemistry.
So the synthesis for instance, is done in water.
Furthermore, we're learning
how to structure our fine powders in order to incorporate
these into large-scale filter devices,
we have to form these bead-type structures.
And so we're learning how to do the structuring process
for essentially an ultimate demonstration
where we can show that these materials perform
in a lot of different waste streams.
So with that, to thank this wonderful research team,
that I've had the opportunity to work with
over the last five years.
Without them, of course, I would have nothing to show you.
They're just wonderful people.
Furthermore, I have to thank the funding,
which makes our chemistry possible.
I'd like to thank you all for your attention,
and I'm happy to take any questions.
Thank you so much, Wendy.
I have a question from the chat where someone asks,
"How much did the MOF composites cost?"
So it depends on the scale.
We estimate that if you were to produce these
on the ton scale, that you're well-below $20 per kilo.
So if you consider the cost of gold,
this is actually quite exciting because one kilo of gold
is like 55,000 USD, I think,
so it's quite a large markup.
Of course at the moment we're working on gram scales,
and the synthesis that you saw is a 400 gram scale.
So we're gonna have to, you know,
work on bringing that cost down with scaling, so.
And that was another question someone asked,
"How scalable are these materials?"
I mean, this material is super-scalable.
You can even make it at room temperature.
So, and we're doing it in water, which is really nice.
So I don't expect to have any problems
with getting up to large scales.
And there are even companies that have been producing
these materials now on the ton scale for quite a while.
Are there any plans for you to start
a company around these materials?
Yeah, we're in the process of doing that at the moment.
So it's really exciting. (laughs)
Sorry, there are so many questions here.
How sustainable are the precursors?
Well we're using iron, which is,
everybody's been talking about cheap
and of course it's sustainable.
The ligands are relatively cheap as well.
Of course, if you can produce the ligands
in a sustainable way,
I have to assume that they come from, you know,
like every, most carbon-based precursors
are coming from oil and things like that.
So yeah, I think overall these materials,
because of the building blocks that we're using,
they're easily made.
All right.
I think we'll move on to our next speaker.
Thank you so much, Wendy.
Sure.
(bright upbeat music)
